title: World's Strongest Man Brian Shaw breaks unofficial deadlift record ahead of Arnold Classic
text:
World's Strongest Man Brian Shaw breaks unofficial deadlift record ahead of Arnold Classic World's Strongest Man Brian Shaw breaks unofficial deadlift record ahead of Arnold Classic LEGENDARY strongman Brian Shaw looks to be in the best shape of his career ahead of the upcoming Arnold Classic – one of the sport’s most revered events. / Published 23rd February 2017 
The 6ft 8ins athlete is looking to win the Arnold for the third time in his career after scooping the title in 2011 and 2015. 
His path to the title has been made a little easier with the absence of Eddie Hall, six-time winner of the UK’s Strongest Man and deadlift world record holder. 
But Shaw isn’t taking any chances on his quest for glory, doubling down on his rigorous training regime with impressive results. 
YOUTUBE TOP DOG: Brian Shaw has cranked up his training in preparation for the Arnold Classic 
The 34-year-old Colorado native pulled an earthshaking 468kg deadlift a haul that, in competition, would have edged Eddie Hall’s world record set last year. 
“In my training session yesterday, I moved somewhere between 50,000lb and 60,000lb of total volume of weight,” Shaw said this week. 
“But if you were to take that over my full career it would be somewhere around 100,000,000lb of weight.” 
And his recent good form has got fans of the sport excited for the Arnold, held in early March later this year. 
YOUTUBE/ROGUE The American is a four-time winner of the World's Strongest Man 
“One of the greatest of all time in this sport,” said one viewer. 
“Well rounded and unbeatable in special events. Still so decent and down-to-earth. 
“How can you not like this dude?” 
The Arnold Classic is seen as one of the most important strongman events in the year – but the four-day fitness expo also showcases a host of other sports including powerlifting, bodybuilding and even some combat sports. Related articles
